channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Taliban Strike Near Palace Inside Kabul
item.description: A complex attack involving gunfire and explosions began early Tuesday near the embassy, the International Security Assistance Force headquarters and the presidential palace.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Signs of Contamination at Plant
item.description: The operator of Japan’s damaged Fukushima nuclear plant said Monday that it had detected a rise in levels of radioactive tritium in seawater near the plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: At Least 37 Miners Die at Gold Mine
item.description: At least 37 gold miners died and many others were injured in the Central African Republic when a pit in which they were working collapsed after heavy rains.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: France Requests Arrest of Shooting Victims’ Relative
item.description: Nine months after the shooting deaths in a French alpine forest of three members of a British-Iraqi family and a passing French cyclist, police arrested a relative of the slain family members.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Assange, Back in News, Never Left U.S. Radar
item.description: Julian Assange and his organization WikiLeaks are being investigated by at least four United States government agencies, along with a grand jury that has subpoenaed witnesses.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR and RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Julian Assange and Birgitta Jonsdottir, in the background, working in Iceland in 2010.

item.title: In Britain, New Inquiry Is Ordered in Bias Killing
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron ordered an investigation into allegations that an officer was directed to look for “dirt” on the family of Stephen Lawrence, a black youth stabbed at a bus stop in 1993.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Empty Seat Deepens a Mystery in Moscow
item.description: A stream of reports from unnamed Russian officials about the travel plans for Edward J. Snowden turned out to be a deception.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Leaker’s Flight Raises Tension Between U.S. and 3 Nations
item.description: The Obama administration escalated its criticism on Monday of Russia, China and Ecuador, the countries that appeared to be protecting Edward J. Snowden, who is wanted on spying charges.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: With Edward J. Snowden apparently in hiding in Moscow, journalists gathered Monday at the Ecuadorean Embassy there.

item.title: Credit Warnings Offer World a Peek Into China’s Secretive Banks
item.description: A warning from the central bank against excessive lending worried investors overseas and brought fears of economic slowdown in China.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Loose credit in China has for many years propped up heavy spending on manufacturing, property and infrastructure.

item.title: St.-Pierre Journal: Resuming the Search for a Pioneering Plane Off a Remote Island
item.description: A retired septuagenarian has committed the past five years to find the plane that carried two French aviators trying an Atlantic crossing from east to west in 1927.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: New evidence suggests that the French aviators Charles Nungesser and François Coli might have crashed off the tiny French island of St.-Pierre, above, about 10 miles from Newfoundland.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Five Soldiers Killed in Kashmir
item.description: Five soldiers were killed and seven others were wounded in what appeared to be a rebel attack on an army convoy in Kashmir on the eve of a visit by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Civilians Flee and Soldiers Die in Clashes in Lebanon
item.description: Fighting between the army and gunmen loyal to a radical Sunni cleric in Sidon reflected how deeply the war in Syria has undermined security in Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Lebanese soldiers helped injured colleagues after fighting with followers of the radical Sunni cleric Sheik Ahmad al-Assir in the southern city of Sidon.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: At Least 41 People Killed in Attacks
item.description: A dozen bombings on Monday in and around Baghdad and north of the city killed at least 41 and wounded 125 others, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Leader Apologizes for Haze
item.description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono of Indonesia on Monday apologized to Singapore and Malaysia for record-setting pollution caused by forest fires in his country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Prime Minister Shuffles Cabinet
item.description: Greece’s conservative prime minister shuffled his cabinet, giving the leader of the Socialist party, Evangelos Venizelos, the dual role of deputy prime minister and foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Responding to Protests, Brazil’s Leader Proposes Changes to System
item.description: President Dilma Rousseff seemed to be aiming for a relatively accommodating response to the anti-establishment demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Snowden Case Has Cold War Aftertaste
item.description: Russia ignored demands by the White House to intercept the N.S.A. leaker and return him to the United States, showing the two countries still have a penchant for that old rivalry from the Soviet era.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Chinese Activist Praises Taiwan’s Democracy
item.description: Chen Guangcheng, who left China last year, began an 18-day visit to Taiwan after leaving New York amid controversy involving his host, New York University.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Merkel Offers Her Election Manifesto
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s platform appeared aimed at German voters on the fringes of her party, which has suffered a string of losses in recent elections.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and CHRIS COTTRELL

item.title: Air Pollution May Have Suppressed Storms, Research Suggests
item.description: To the list of ways humanity seems to have altered the earth, add another candidate: Air pollution may have had a major soothing influence on storm cycles in the North Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: A storm surging toward the mid-Atlantic. Clean air acts may have helped return storm cycles to a more natural state.

item.title: Solar Boat Harnessed for Research
item.description: The first boat to circumnavigate the globe using only the sun’s power is now helping a team of scientists studying ocean currents and climate change.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:description: Turanor Planetsolar, a 100-foot catamaran with solar panels covering the flat top deck, made a stop in New York City as it followed the Gulf Stream.

item.title: Berlusconi Is Sentenced to Seven Years in Sex Case, but Can Still Appeal Verdict
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian leader, was expected to appeal a court ruling that he paid for sex with a minor.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: People celebrated outside a court in Milan, after the former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was given a seven-year sentence.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 24
item.description: The Indian cricket team won the I.C.C. Champions Trophy in England on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Captain of the Indian cricket team, Mahendra Singh Dhoni, center, with the I.C.C. Champions Trophy, flanked by teammates, Shikhar Dhawan, left, and Ravindra Jadeja in Birmingham, England. India defeated the hosts in the tournament final on Sunday.

item.title: Global Health: Rubella Epidemics in Japan and Poland
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued travel warnings for women who are pregnant or may be pregnant because the disease can cause stillbirth and birth defects.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. M cNEIL Jr.

item.title: Pakistan Premier Says Former Military Ruler Will Be Charged With Treason
item.description: In a speech to Parliament on Monday, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said that the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf had to answer for his acts during his years in power.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
